sn22.84:4.2: Now at that time Venerable Tissa, the Buddha’s paternal cousin, informed a number of mendicants:
sn22.84:4.3: “Reverends, my body feels like it’s drugged. I’m disorientated, the teachings don’t inspire me, and dullness and drowsiness fill my mind. I live the spiritual life dissatisfied, and have doubts about the teachings.”
sn22.84:5.1: Then several mendicants went up to the Buddha,
sn22.84:5.2: bowed, sat down to one side,
sn22.84:5.3: and told him what had happened.
sn22.84:6.1: So the Buddha said to a certain monk:
sn22.84:6.2: “Please, mendicant, in my name tell the mendicant Tissa that the Teacher calls him.”
sn22.84:6.3: “Yes, sir,” that monk replied. He went to Tissa
sn22.84:6.6: “Yes, reverend,” Tissa replied. He went to the Buddha,
sn22.84:6.7: bowed, and sat down to one side.
sn22.84:6.9: “Is it really true, Tissa, that you informed a number of mendicants that
sn22.84:6.10: your body feels like it’s drugged …
sn22.84:6.11: and you have doubts about the teachings?”
sn22.84:6.13: “What do you think, Tissa? If you’re not rid of greed, desire, fondness, thirst, passion, and craving for form, when that form decays and perishes, will it give rise to sorrow, crying, pain, sadness, and distress?”
sn22.84:7.3: when you’re not rid of greed for form.
sn22.84:7.4: If you’re not rid of greed, desire, fondness, thirst, passion, and craving for feeling …
sn22.84:8.3: consciousness, when that consciousness decays and perishes, will it give rise to sorrow, crying, pain, sadness, and distress?”
sn22.84:9.3: when you’re not rid of greed for form.
sn22.84:9.4: What do you think, Tissa? If you are rid of greed, desire, fondness, thirst, passion, and craving for form, when that form decays and perishes, will it give rise to sorrow, crying, pain, sadness, and distress?”
sn22.84:10.3: when you are rid of greed for form …
sn22.84:11.4: What do you think, Tissa? Is form permanent or impermanent?”
sn22.84:11.13: They understand: ‘… there is no return to any state of existence.’”
sn22.84:12.1: Suppose, Tissa, there were two people.
sn22.84:12.2: One was not skilled in the path, the other was.
sn22.84:12.3: The one not skilled in the path would question the one skilled in the path,
sn22.84:12.5: ‘Come, good man, this is the path.
sn22.84:12.7: and you’ll see a fork in the road. Ignore the left, and take the right-hand path.
sn22.84:12.9: and you’ll see a dark forest grove.
sn22.84:12.11: and you’ll see an expanse of low-lying swampland.
sn22.84:12.13: and you’ll see a large, steep cliff.
sn22.84:12.15: and you’ll see level, cleared parkland.’
sn22.84:13.1: I’ve made up this simile to make a point.
sn22.84:13.2: And this is what it means.
sn22.84:13.3: ‘A person who is not skilled in the path’ is a term for an ordinary uneducated person.
sn22.84:13.4: ‘A person who is skilled in the path’ is a term for the Realized One, the Perfect One, the fully awakened Buddha.
sn22.84:13.5: ‘A fork in the road’ is a term for doubt.
sn22.84:13.6: ‘The left-hand path’ is a term for the wrong eightfold path, that is,
sn22.84:13.9: ‘The right-hand path’ is a term for the noble eightfold path, that is,
sn22.84:13.12: ‘A dark forest grove’ is a term for ignorance.
sn22.84:13.13: ‘An expanse of low-lying swampland’ is a term for sensual pleasures.
sn22.84:13.14: ‘A large, steep cliff’ is a term for anger and distress.
sn22.84:13.15: ‘Level, cleared parkland’ is a term for extinguishment.
sn22.84:13.17: I’m here to advise you, to support you, and to teach you.”
sn22.84:14.1: This is what the Buddha said.
sn22.84:14.2: Uplifted, Venerable Tissa approved of what the Buddha said.
